We have fly agaric in our back yard. According to my research (reading articles,) the mushroom used to be used to trap flies. Bits of the mushroom would be floated in water or milk, and the flies would land on them and drown.

Also, while they contain psychedelic alkaloids, they also contain alkaloids that cause nausea and vomiting. North dwelling people used to feed the mushroom to reindeer. The liver would decontaminate the nausea inducing substances, and the psychedelic substances would be excreted in the urine. They would then drink the urine. The resulting reduction in the fear response would make them quite effective beserker-type warriors.

The Fly Agaric are commonly eaten by reindeer, which I don't think they get high off but their bodies filter out a lot of the toxins that are harmful to humans and so some of the hallucinogenic compounds remain in their urine. So people used to drink the reindeer urine to get high. With the mushroom and reindeer being linked to Christmas some  people think Christmas' origins are from hallucinogenic rituals, some go a step further and think most religions have similar origins. Which is certainly a lot more believable that what religions claim to be true and explains why they claim those things to be true... Who knows? But it's an interesting topic.

With many mushroom species, poisonous look-alikes can fool (and kill!) even experienced foragers. But not lion’s mane! One of the best things about lion’s mane is that it does not have any poisonous look-alikes, so even if you are completely new to mushroom foraging, is almost certainly safe to eat.

The bizarre "intelligence" of fungi is utterly fascinating. I like to grow shiitake mushrooms as a bit of a hobby. One thing I've noticed helps bring the mycelium to fruit is to give the log a good whack. Drop it, hit it, whatever, just give it a jostle. The mycelium "thinks" that a branch has fallen next to it, or that it fell off a part of a tree, and almost always develops pins and spores. It "thinks" there's fresh deadwood to get into!
Edit: The Bleeding Tooth mushroom looks utterly delicious. Forbidden Gusher.

Ibotenic acid is much more toxic than muscimol. Ibotenic acid is converted to muscimol through decarboxylation, like how you decarboxylate THCa to THC for edible consumption. There's really no excuse for saying ibotenic acid is one of the psychoactive chemicals like it's just something that is consumed with the mushroom when everybody who uses the mushroom decarboxylates for safety purposes. It's also not a psychedelic mushroom, in the traditional sense of psychedelics. It's not like doing psilocybin. I've never even done fly agaric, but that's because I've read all about it and it doesn't really sound like something I want to mess with, and I've done a lot of psychedelic mushrooms. If this was my primary source of info about it I might just think I can just eat it right off the ground and have a good time, which isn't the case judging from everything else I've read. They have to be prepared right to convert the ibotenic acid to muscimol, or you could have some serious problems beyond what you might have with just muscimol alone, which alone sounds like a serious drug, though not physically dangerous and neurotoxic like ibotenic acid.

The reason why the Flyer Garrick has its name, is because it contains ibotenic acid and muscimol, which are a powerful insecticide.
It was quite popular in Germany to control insect populations in Milk farms until the 1970. The ibotenic acid and muscimol are supposed to be fat soluble.
The application is to add a dry slices or two in a bowl of warm milk.
The milk is the laid out for the flies for example in the cow shed.
The flies love the laced milk, gorge themselves on it and will be dead within hours.

#SciShow, look at the story behind the best engineering designers of non-human life forms. Slime moulds! They've been used to "design" road and rail networks using only blobs of oatmeal. The scientists put the blobs in the position of, for example, railway stations in (iirc) Tokyo. The mould was placed in the middle and went looking for food. I won't spoil the outcome, but it's absolutely worth looking into! They're even being used to control robots...

Any discussion of wild fungi and their characteristics should include stern warnings that...
.
(a) there are no 'rules of thumb' for identifying edible species,
(b) many edible mushrooms have poisonous lookalikes,
(c) when starting, a field guide is no replacement for hunting with someone experienced,
(d) eat small amounts the first time when trying any species; even if properly identified allergic reactions can occur,
(e) save a sample of all collections for analysis in case of error & poisoning, and
(f) beware of wishful thinking. if in doubt, throw it out.

I'm pretty sure that the common name of A. muscaria derives from it's use against insects: it was mashed into milk, which acted as a bait for houseflies. Upon consuming the milk, the chemicals in the mushroom made the fly lethargic and uncoordinated, hence easy to swat.

I once found a huge growth of https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laetiporus_sulphureus  on my neighbor's tree.  I had just recently read http://www.thesneeze.com/2007/steve-dont-eat-it---the-tree-brain.php  so I knew exactly what it was.  I politely asked him if I could harvest the thing, and while he was weirded out a little by my request, he still graciously said ok.

That fungus was delicious!  Although, there was so much of it that by the end, I was getting just a wee bit sick of it, but that's just because I didn't do anything fancier with it than cooking it in browned butter.  Mebbe next time, I'll find ways to complement the flavors.

In german, the Fly Agaric is named "Fliegenpilz", where "Pilz" means mushroom and "Fliegen" is plural for flies. No other meaning possible. Also, for centuries farmers used to cut this mushroom into little pieces and mix it with warm milk and put it out on a plate to kill thousands of flies. So the name is related to its function, and at least in central Europe that function was as an insecticide specifically to decimate flies.

If you have never had any other mushroom besides portabella, I highly recommend you give some gourmet edible mushrooms a try. Some of them are absolutely delicious, my favorites are oyster, mitake, and chanterelle. Always amazing when sauteed well over medium heat with some chopped onion and olive oil. I miss mushroom foraging season here in Wisconsin.
